thread.title: Body of woman discovered in Marissa landfill during St. Louis missing-person inquiry
thread.title_full: Body of woman discovered in Marissa landfill during St. Louis missing-person inquiry

author: From staff reports
title: Body of woman discovered in Marissa landfill during St. Louis missing-person inquiry
text:
Law and order Close 
St. Louis police investigate after a body was discovered at a landfill in Marissa on Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017. Photo courtesy KTVI Body of woman discovered in Marissa landfill during St. Louis missing-person inquiry From staff reports 2 hrs ago ( … ) 
St. Louis police investigate after a body was discovered at a landfill in Marissa on Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017. Photo courtesy KTVI 
MARISSA • Cadaver dogs found the body of a young woman in a landfill Tuesday after St. Louis homicide detectives seeking a missing person traced the trash collection route from a city neighborhood to the dump, Marissa police chief Tom Prather said Tuesday. 
Prather said the dog team located the body about 10:30 a.m. in an area in which Waste Management Inc., which runs the Cottonwood Hills landfill, determined where the trash would have been buried. Prather said St. Louis detectives contacted his office Monday that they were following the trail in a missing-person case. 
Waste Management Inc. takes waste from the city Refuse Department and operates the Cottonwood Hills landfill in Marissa. Prather said detectives suspected that the body of a woman missing since last Thursday, had been put in an alley trash container in the city. 
Prather said investigators had not identified the body but added, "We suspect it is the missing female." He said the Illinois State Police and the St. Clair County coroner's office also were working on the case. 
St. Louis police identified the missing woman they were seeking as Brandy Renee Morrison, 23, whose family reported her missing Thursday. 
Jeannette Morrison, the missing woman's aunt, said she had talked with relatives Tuesday about the case. 
"I just pray to God it's not her," she told a reporter. 
Marissa is about 30 miles southeast of downtown St. Louis.
